title: Clinical Significance Cutoffs
text: imagine dimensional outcome, e.g., measure depression, clinical functional population form two distinct distributions dimension. specific example (see figure ), clinical population (red line) can described normal distribution M = 32 SD = 7. functional population (blue line) can described normal distribution M = 10 SD = 7.

title: Clinical Significance Cutoffs
text: reasonable cutoff clinical functional population ly . Jacobson et al. (1984) Jacobson & Truax (1991) proposed cutoffs \(\) \(b\) \[= M_{clin} - 2 SD_{clin}\\= 32 - 2\cdot7\\=18\] \[b = M_{fun} + 2 SD_{clin}\\b=10+2\cdot7\\b=24\] \(M_{clin}\) \(M_{fun}\) means clinical functional population \(SD_{clin}\) standard deviation clinical population. note cutoffs incorporate clinical population’s standard deviation “starting point” different. \(\), clinical population’s mean \(b\) functional population’s mean. importance direction beneficial effect. example, lower depression score beneficial patient. examples, opposite may true, e.g., measure quality life, higher values desirable. case, plus minus signs formulas switched. incorporate cutoffs \(\) \(b\) figure , get following picture.  overlapping distributions, \(\) seems conservative \(b\) seems liberal deciding whether patient moved clinical functional population.

title: Clinical Significance Cutoffs
text: reasonable cutoff, however, may one incorporates , mean standard deviation, populations. \(c\) designed . defined \[c = \frac{SD_{fun}M_{clin} + SD_{clin}M_{fun}}{SD_{fun} + SD_{clin}}\\c=\frac{7\cdot32+7\cdot10}{7+7}\\c=21\] \(M\) \(SD\) mean standard deviation indexes \(fun\) \(clin\) indicating functional clinical population. cutoff lays populations can seen figure .  , \(c\) generally recommended. , descriptive statistics functional population, always use \(c\)! ensures comparability clinical significance analyses. deviate approach, clearly explain give detailed reasons . obstacle might availability descriptives functional population needed calculate \(c\). However, known common instruments psychological research. , might good idea determine metrics first!
code: distributions +   geom_vline(xintercept = c, linetype = "dashed") +   geom_label(aes(label = "c"), x = c, y = 0.05, label.r = unit(0, "lines"))

title: Clinical Significance Cutoffs
text: simple way check cutoffs check_cutoff()
code: library(clinicalsignificance)  check_cutoff(m_clinical = 32, sd_clinical = 7, m_functional = 10, sd_functional = 7, type = "c")

title: Clinical Significance Cutoffs
text: Hageman & Arrindell (1999) proposed \(\), \(b\), \(c\) expressed true scores principles classical test theory. obtain true scores \(\), \(b\), \(c\), .e., \(a_{true}\), \(b_{true}\), \(c_{true}\), standard deviations formulas proposed Jacobson & Truax (1991) must multiplied respective reliability. \[a_{true} = M_{clin} - 2 SD_{clin} \sqrt{r_{xx(clin)}}\] \[\sqrt{r_{xx(clin)}} = \frac{SD_{clin}^2 - S_E}{SD_{clin}^2}\] \[S_E = SD_{sample}\sqrt{1 - r_{sample}}\] \(SD_{sample}\) \(r_{sample}\) standard deviation reliability coefficient specific sample. sample may clinical functional population. reliability coefficient , , measure internal consistency. \(b_{true}\) defined \[b_{true} = M_{fun} + 2 SD_{clin}\sqrt{r_{xx(clin)}}\] Bear mind direction beneficial importance well. formulas outcome lower score indicates beneficial outcome. higher values desirable, plus minus signs formulas \(a_{true}\) \(b_{true}\) must switched. \(c_{true}\) defined \[c_{true} = \frac{SD_{fun}\sqrt{r_{xx(fun)}}M_{clin} + SD_{clin}\sqrt{r_{xx(clin)}}M_{fun}}{SD_{fun}\sqrt{r_{xx(fun)}} + SD_{clin}\sqrt{r_{xx(clin)}}}\] \[\sqrt{r_{xx(fun)}} = \frac{SD_{fun}^2 - S_E}{SD_{fun}^2}\]

title: Clinical Significance Plots
code: anxiety_results <- anxiety %>%    clinical_significance(     id = subject,      time = measurement,      outcome = anxiety,      pre = 0,      post = 4,      reliability = 0.80,      m_functional = 10,      sd_functional = 7,      type = "c"   )  plot(anxiety_results, upper_limit = 60)

title: Clinical Significance Plots
text: lower instrument score corresponds beneficial outcome, categories clinical significance plot can interpreted according figure .  higher instrument score corresponds beneficial outcome, categories clinical significance plot can interpreted according figure . plot , flipped along diagonal indicates change.

title: Clinical Significance Plots
text: plot automatically changes according specified clinical significance method.   clinical significance analyses employing HLM method (Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002), individual trajectories empirical Bayes slopes can plotted well.
code: anxiety_results_ha <- anxiety %>%    clinical_significance(     id = subject,      time = measurement,      outcome = anxiety,      pre = 0,      post = 4,      reliability = 0.80,      m_functional = 10,      sd_functional = 7,      type = "c",     method = "HA"   )  plot(anxiety_results_ha, upper_limit = 60) anxiety_results_en <- anxiety %>%    clinical_significance(     id = subject,      time = measurement,      outcome = anxiety,      pre = 0,      post = 4,      reliability = 0.80,      m_functional = 10,      sd_functional = 7,      type = "c",     method = "EN"   )  plot(anxiety_results_en, upper_limit = 60) anxiety_results_hlm <- anxiety %>%    clinical_significance(     id = subject,     time = measurement,     outcome = anxiety,     method = "HLM"   )  plot(anxiety_results_hlm, which = "trajectory") plot(anxiety_results_hlm, which = "slope")

title: Clinical Significance Plots
text: can choose different categories groups colored separately. clinical significance analysis contains grouping variable, automatically shown corresponding plot.  Alternatively, can color individual clinical significance categories.   categories .  Trajectories slopes HLM can colored well.   clinicalsignificance uses ggplot2 internally, can manipulate plots liking.
code: anxiety_results_grouped <- anxiety %>%    clinical_significance(     id = subject,      time = measurement,      outcome = anxiety,      pre = 0,      post = 4,      reliability = 0.80,      m_functional = 10,      sd_functional = 7,      type = "c",     group = treatment   )  plot(anxiety_results_grouped, upper_limit = 60) plot(anxiety_results, upper_limit = 60, show = "recovered") plot(anxiety_results, upper_limit = 60, show = "improved") plot(anxiety_results, upper_limit = 60, show = "category") plot(anxiety_results_hlm, which = "trajectory", show = "recovered") plot(anxiety_results_hlm, which = "slope", show = "recovered") plot(anxiety_results_hlm, which = "trajectory", show = "recovered") +   facet_wrap(~ recovered) +   theme_minimal()

title: Clinical Significance Plots
text: can change display RCI band, .e., color transparency.  HA method (Hageman & Arrindell, 1999) considers band around post measurement cutoff, can plotted well.
code: plot(anxiety_results, upper_limit = 60, rci_fill = "blue", rci_alpha = 0.2) plot(anxiety_results_ha, upper_limit = 60, include_cutoff_band = TRUE)

title: Clinical Significance Plots
text: recommended include cutoff clinical functional population. default, plotted can omitted well.
code: plot(anxiety_results, upper_limit = 60, include_cutoff = FALSE)

title: Clinical Significance Plots
text: default, generic plot labels used. can adjust make figure publication ready.
code: plot(anxiety_results_grouped,       upper_limit = 60,       x_lab = "Anxiety Pre",       y_lab = "Anxiety Post",       color_lab = "Condition")

title: Get started
text: Suppose intervention enhances placebo effect antidepressants routine care. Claus et al. (2020) conducted study examining intervention routine care setting depressive disorders comparing group patients receiving treatment usual (TAU) group patients receiving placebo amplification intervention (PA). assessed patients four times treatment measurements carried pre treatment, two times treatment one time post treatment. original study data included package claus_2020. mainly contains column identifying individual patients (id), column indicating measurement (time values 1–4), four outcomes assessed (bdi, shaps, , hamd), well column indicating experimental condition (treatment two experimental conditions TAU PA). Let’s consider primary outcome study, Beck Depression Inventory second edition (Beck et al., 1996), known BDI-II. scores per patient measurement can found column bdi. First, let’s plot results. load tidyverse, gain access package ggplot2 others data wrangling.  can see BDI-II scores seemed declining course treatment. effect meaningful practical patients?
code: library(clinicalsignificance)  claus_2020 #> # A tibble: 172 × 9 #>       id   age sex    treatment  time   bdi shaps   who  hamd #>    <dbl> <dbl> <fct>  <fct>     <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #>  1     1    54 Male   TAU           1    33     9     0    25 #>  2     1    54 Male   TAU           2    28     6     3    17 #>  3     1    54 Male   TAU           3    28     9     7    13 #>  4     1    54 Male   TAU           4    27     8     3    13 #>  5     2    52 Female PA            1    26    11     2    15 #>  6     2    52 Female PA            2    26    10     0    16 #>  7     2    52 Female PA            3    25    10     0     7 #>  8     2    52 Female PA            4    19     9     3    11 #>  9     3    54 Male   PA            1    15     2     0    28 #> 10     3    54 Male   PA            2    13     5     9    17 #> # … with 162 more rows library(tidyverse)  claus_2020 %>%    mutate(time = as_factor(time)) %>%    ggplot(aes(time, bdi)) +   geom_boxplot() #> Warning: Removed 9 rows containing non-finite values (stat_boxplot).

title: Get started
text: Additionally statistical significance testing, clinical significance testing great way make sense results . , can examine given patient changes reliably crosses line clinical functional population practical relevance patient. functional population particular example examined Kühner et al. (2007), determined mean BDI-II score M = 7.69 (SD = 7.52) non-clinical German population. study Claus et al. (2020), reliability BDI-II McDonald’s \(\omega\) = 0.801. values, information need calculate clinical significance clinical_significance(). Note Claus et al. (2020) assessed patients four times study, clinical significance analysis usually done pre post assessments alone (exception HLM method), need specify pre assessment (pre = 1) post assessment (post = 4). now can see 10 patients categorized recovered. means 10 patients clinical population pre intervention functional population post treatment showed reliable change. 8 patients showed reliable change change clinical functional population. 22 patients change reliably – change greater error measurement. Fortunately, patients deteriorated harmed study period. can obtain detailed summary incorporated calculated values summary(). can see 40 participants sufficient data used analysis (pre post scores). given chosen cutoff ("c") well value (21.02). Additionally, can plot results plot(). know upper limit BDI-II 63, can specify make plot comprehensible.  wish, can plot clinical significance categories well.
code: results <- claus_2020 %>%    clinical_significance(     id = id,     time = time,     outcome = bdi,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     m_functional = 7.69,     sd_functional = 7.52,     reliability = 0.801,     type = "c"   )  results #> Clinical Significance Results (JT) #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Recovered    | 10 |   0.250 #> Improved     |  8 |   0.200 #> Unchanged    | 22 |   0.550 #> Deteriorated |  0 |   0.000 #> Harmed       |  0 |   0.000 summary(results) #>  #> Clinical Significance Results #>  #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which #> 40 (93%) could be included in the analysis. #>  #> The JT method for calculating cutoffs and reliable change was #> chosen and the outcome variable was "bdi". #>  #> The cutoff type was "c" with a value of 21.02 based on #> the following population characteristics (with lower values #> representing a beneficial outcome): #>  #> Population Characteristics #>  #> M Clinical | SD Clinical | M Functional | SD Functional #> ------------------------------------------------------- #> 35.48      | 8.16        | 7.69         | 7.52          #>  #>  #> The instrument's reliability was set to 0.8  #>  #> Individual Level Results #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Recovered    | 10 |   0.250 #> Improved     |  8 |   0.200 #> Unchanged    | 22 |   0.550 #> Deteriorated |  0 |   0.000 #> Harmed       |  0 |   0.000 plot(results, upper_limit = 63) plot(results, upper_limit = 63, show = "category")

title: Get started
text: study compared two groups (TAU PA) latter one receiving intervention interest, grouping variable can specified well. function call identical call exception provide column containing groups (treatment data set). output, can see patients recovered improved PA group (intervention) compared TAU group (control). patients categorized unchanged TAU group PA group. results can also plotted.
code: results_grouped <- claus_2020 %>%    clinical_significance(     id = id,     time = time,     outcome = bdi,     pre = 1,     post = 4,     m_functional = 7.69,     sd_functional = 7.52,     reliability = 0.801,     type = "c",     group = treatment   )  results_grouped #> Clinical Significance Results (JT) #>  #> Group | Category     |  n | Percent #> ----------------------------------- #> TAU   | Recovered    |  3 |   0.158 #> TAU   | Improved     |  2 |   0.105 #> TAU   | Unchanged    | 14 |   0.737 #> TAU   | Deteriorated |  0 |   0.000 #> TAU   | Harmed       |  0 |   0.000 #> PA    | Recovered    |  7 |   0.333 #> PA    | Improved     |  6 |   0.286 #> PA    | Unchanged    |  8 |   0.381 #> PA    | Deteriorated |  0 |   0.000 #> PA    | Harmed       |  0 |   0.000 plot(results_grouped, upper_limit = 63)

title: Get started
text: several proposed methods conduct clinical significance analysis packages contains . Available Jacobson & Truax (JT, Jacobson & Truax, 1991), default Gulliksen, Lord & Novick (GLN, Hsu, 1989, 1995) Hsu, Linn & Lord (HLL, Hsu, 1989) Edwards & Nunnally (EN, Speer, 1992) Nunnally & Kotsch (NK, Nunnally & Kotsch, 1983) Hageman & Arrindell (HA, Hageman & Arrindell, 1999) Hierarchical Linear Modeling (HLM, Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002) can easily applied via method argument, e.g., one can analyse data sophisticated complicated HA method (Hageman & Arrindell, 1999).
code: results_ha <- claus_2020 %>%    clinical_significance(     id = id,     time = time,     outcome = bdi,      pre = 1,     post = 4,     m_functional = 7.69,     sd_functional = 7.52,     reliability = 0.801,     type = "c",     method = "HA"   )  results_ha #> Clinical Significance Results (HA Individual Level) #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Recovered    |  8 |   0.200 #> Improved     | 17 |   0.425 #> Unchanged    | 15 |   0.375 #> Deteriorated |  0 |   0.000 #> Harmed       |  0 |   0.000 #>  #> Clinical Significance Results (HA Group Level) #>  #> Category   | Percent #> -------------------- #> Changed    |   0.841 #> Functional |   0.353  plot(results_ha, upper_limit = 63)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Benedikt Claus. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Claus B (2022). clinicalsignificance: Determine Clinical Significance Clinical Trials. R package version 1.0.0.
code: @Manual{,   title = {clinicalsignificance: Determine the Clinical Significance in Clinical Trials},   author = {Benedikt Claus},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 1.0.0}, }

what: An R-Package for Clinical Significance Analyses
title: An R-Package for Clinical Significance Analyses
text: goal package provide necessary tools analyses clinical significance clinical intervention studies. contrast statistical significance, assesses probable treatment effect, clinical significance can used determine treatment effect practical use meaningful patients.

title: An R-Package for Clinical Significance Analyses
text: can install development version clinicalsignificance GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("pedscience/clinicalsignificance")

title: An R-Package for Clinical Significance Analyses
text: Given tidy dataset, employed instrument’s reliability descriptives (M SD) functional population, clinical significance study can easily assessed. can receive detailed summary analysis plot results
code: library(clinicalsignificance)  results <- claus_2020 %>%    clinical_significance(     id = id,      time = time,      outcome = bdi,      pre = 1,      post = 4,      reliability = 0.81,      m_functional = 8,      sd_functional = 8,      type = "c"   )  results #> Clinical Significance Results (JT) #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Recovered    | 10 |   0.250 #> Improved     |  9 |   0.225 #> Unchanged    | 21 |   0.525 #> Deteriorated |  0 |   0.000 #> Harmed       |  0 |   0.000 summary(results) #>  #> Clinical Significance Results #>  #> There were 43 participants in the whole dataset of which 40 (93%) #> could be included in the analysis. #>  #> The JT method for calculating cutoffs and reliable change was chosen #> and the outcome variable was "bdi". #>  #> The cutoff type was "c" with a value of 21.6 based on the following #> population characteristics (with lower values representing a #> beneficial outcome): #>  #> Population Characteristics #>  #> M Clinical | SD Clinical | M Functional | SD Functional #> ------------------------------------------------------- #> 35.48      | 8.16        | 8            | 8             #>  #>  #> The instrument's reliability was set to 0.81  #>  #> Individual Level Results #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Recovered    | 10 |   0.250 #> Improved     |  9 |   0.225 #> Unchanged    | 21 |   0.525 #> Deteriorated |  0 |   0.000 #> Harmed       |  0 |   0.000 plot(results)

title: An R-Package for Clinical Significance Analyses
text: Jacobson et al. (1984) criticized, along researchers, vast majority research psychological intervention research based statistical significance testing. procedure comes two major disadvantages: first, treatment effects based groups lack information individual participants. Second, significance test lacks practical relevance. One can think hypothetical intervention expands life expectancy 1 day. enough participants incorporated significance test, one can virtually guarantee significant result although agree intervention lacks practical relevance. Therefore, Jacobson et al. (1984) postulated additional procedure categorizes patient based /individual change. patient (reliably) moves dysfunctional functional population, patient’s change clinically significant. case depicted figure . Let’s suppose instrument assessing depressive symptoms. clinical population patients major depression may score average M = 34 SD = 8 instrument. functional population (case sample people without major depression) may score average M = 8 SD = 8 instrument. now individual patient major depression scores 32 depression instrument intervention (black point clinical population) 12 intervention (black point functional population) therefore crossed cutoff two populations (black line ), patient changed clinically significant (change beyond error measurement instrument).

title: Anxiety Data — anxiety
text: fictional clinical trial, participants split belong either medical placebo ("Placebo") psychotherapeutic intervention ("Intervention") group. underwent outpatient treatment followed 5 measurements fictional anxiety score measured. anxiety score may range 0 - 60. functional population (.e., non-anxious individuals) can expected mean score M = 8 points standard deviation SD = 4.

what: Check the Clinical Significance Cutoff Based on Population Descriptives — check_cutoff
title: Check the Clinical Significance Cutoff Based on Population Descriptives — check_cutoff
text: Check Clinical Significance Cutoff Based Population Descriptives

title: Check the Clinical Significance Cutoff Based on Population Descriptives — check_cutoff
code: check_cutoff(   object = NULL,   m_clinical,   sd_clinical,   m_functional = NA,   sd_functional = NA,   type = c("a", "b", "c"),   better_is = c("lower", "higher"),   resolution = 300 )

title: Check the Clinical Significance Cutoff Based on Population Descriptives — check_cutoff
text: object object class clinisig. optional can used visualize cutoffs conducting clinical significance analysis. m_clinical Mean clinical population sd_clinical SD clinical population m_functional M functional population sd_functional SD functional population type Cutoff type. Available "", "b", "c". Defaults "" (see details information cutoff choose) better_is direction means better outcome employed outcome? Available "lower" (lower outcome scores desirable, default) "higher" (higher outcome scores desirable) resolution Curve resolution (number points drawn). may improve smoothness highly peaked curves.

title: Check the Clinical Significance Cutoff Based on Population Descriptives — check_cutoff
text: ggplot2

title: Check the Clinical Significance Cutoff Based on Population Descriptives — check_cutoff
code: # Check cutoff with manually specified values check_cutoff(m_clinical = 40, sd_clinical = 12, m_functional = 10, sd_functional = 12)    # Or check the cutoff after you conducted a clinical significance analysis results <- jacobson_1989 %>%   clinical_significance(     id = subject,     time = time,     outcome = gds,     pre = "pre",     reliability = 0.80,     m_functional = 30,     sd_functional = 7,     type = "c"   )  check_cutoff(results)

title: Placebo Amplification Data — claus_2020
text: dataset containing data Claus et al. (2020). routine inpatient setting unipolar depressive disorders implemented intervention sought amplify placebo response antidepressants. study, two groups compared: treatment usual (TAU) placebo amplification (PA). Participants examined four times treatment.

title: Placebo Amplification Data — claus_2020
code: claus_2020

title: Placebo Amplification Data — claus_2020
text: object class tbl_df 172 rows 9 columns. id Participant ID age Age sex Sex treatment Treatment (TAU treatment usual PA placebo amplification) time Measurement bdi Beck Depression Inventory (2nd Edition) score shaps Snaith-Hamilton Pleasure Scale score -Five Well-Index score hamd Hamilton Rating Scale Depression score

title: Placebo Amplification Data — claus_2020
text: https://osf.io/rc754/

title: Placebo Amplification Data — claus_2020
text: Claus, B. B., Scherbaum, N., & Bonnet, U. (2020). Effectiveness Adjunctive Psychotherapeutic Intervention Developed Enhancing Placebo Effect Antidepressants Used within Inpatient-Treatment Program Major Depression: Pragmatic Parallel-Group, Randomized Controlled Trial. Psychotherapy Psychosomatics, 89(4), 258-260. https://doi.org/10.1159/000505855

title: Clinical Significance — clinical_significance
text: function conducts clinical significance analysis determining patients changed reliably moved clinical functional population study.

title: Clinical Significance — clinical_significance
code: clinical_significance(   data,   id,   time,   outcome,   group = NULL,   pre = NULL,   post = NULL,   m_functional = NA,   sd_functional = NA,   type = "a",   reliability,   reliability_post,   better_is = c("lower", "higher"),   method = c("JT", "GLN", "HLL", "EN", "NK", "HA", "HLM") )

title: Clinical Significance — clinical_significance
text: data tidy data frame id Participant ID time Time variable outcome Outcome variable group Grouping variable pre Pre measurement post Post measurement m_functional Mean functional population sd_functional Standard deviation functional population type Cutoff type. Available "", "b", "c". Defaults "" (see details information cutoff choose) reliability instrument's reliability estimate. selected NK method, specified reliability instrument's pre measurement reliability reliability_post instrument's reliability post measurement. relevant NK method better_is direction means better outcome employed outcome? Available "lower" (lower outcome scores desirable, default) "higher" (higher outcome scores desirable) method Clinical significance method. Available "JT" (Jacobson & Truax, 1991, default) "GLN" (Gulliksen, Lord, Novick; Hsu, 1989, Hsu, 1995) "HLL" (Hsu, Linn & Nord; Hsu, 1989) "EN" (Edwards & Nunnally; Speer, 1992) "NK" (Nunnally & Kotsch, 1983), requires reliability estimate post measurement. supplied, reliability reliability_post assumed equal "HA" (Hageman & Arrindell, 1999) "HLM" (Hierarchical Linear Modeling; Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002), requires least three measurements per patient

title: Clinical Significance — clinical_significance
text: S3 object class clinisig

title: Clinical Significance — clinical_significance
text: default, JT method used, methods implemented (see description arguments). generally recommended use cutoff "c", thus, incorporating information clinical functional population cutoff calculation.

title: Clinical Significance — clinical_significance
text: Jacobson, N. S., & Truax, P. (1991). Clinical significance: statistical approach defining meaningful change psychotherapy research. Journal Consulting Clinical Psychology, 59(1), 12–19. https://doi.org/10.1037//0022-006X.59.1.12 Hsu, L. M. (1989). Reliable changes psychotherapy: Taking account regression toward mean. Behavioral Assessment, 11(4), 459–467. Hsu, L. M. (1995). Regression toward mean associated measurement error identification improvement deterioration psychotherapy. Journal Consulting Clinical Psychology, 63(1), 141–144. https://doi.org/10.1037//0022-006x.63.1.141 Speer, D. C. (1992). Clinically significant change: Jacobson Truax (1991) revisited. Journal Consulting Clinical Psychology, 60(3), 402–408. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-006X.60.3.402 Nunnally, J. C., & Kotsch, W. E. (1983). Studies individual subjects: Logic methods analysis. British Journal Clinical Psychology, 22(2), 83–93. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.2044-8260.1983.tb00582.x Hageman, W. J., & Arrindell, W. . (1999). Establishing clinically significant change: increment precision distinction individual group level analysis. Behaviour Research Therapy, 37(12), 1169–1193. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0005-7967(99)00032-7 Raudenbush, S. W., & Bryk, . S. (2002). Hierarchical Linear Models - Applications Data Analysis Methods (2nd ed.). Sage Publications.

title: Clinical Significance — clinical_significance
code: # Clinical significane for "negative" outcomes (lower values are desirable) jacobson_1989 %>%   clinical_significance(     id = subject,     time = time,     outcome = gds,     pre = "pre",     reliability = 0.80   ) #> Clinical Significance Results (JT) #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Recovered    | 10 |   0.385 #> Improved     |  4 |   0.154 #> Unchanged    | 12 |   0.462 #> Deteriorated |  0 |   0.000 #> Harmed       |  0 |   0.000   # Clinical significane for "positive" outcomes (higher values are desirable) jacobson_1989 %>%   clinical_significance(     id = subject,     time = time,     outcome = das,     pre = "pre",     reliability = 0.80,     better_is = "higher"   ) #> Clinical Significance Results (JT) #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Recovered    | 10 |   0.333 #> Improved     |  6 |   0.200 #> Unchanged    | 13 |   0.433 #> Deteriorated |  1 |   0.033 #> Harmed       |  0 |   0.000   # Clinical significance incorporating descriptives of a functional population. # Make sure to select type = "c" to incorporate the specified functional # descriptives. jacobson_1989 %>%   clinical_significance(     id = subject,     time = time,     outcome = gds,     pre = "pre",     reliability = 0.80,     m_functional = 30,     sd_functional = 7,     type = "c"   ) #> Clinical Significance Results (JT) #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Recovered    |  3 |   0.115 #> Improved     | 11 |   0.423 #> Unchanged    | 12 |   0.462 #> Deteriorated |  0 |   0.000 #> Harmed       |  0 |   0.000   # Change the clinical significance method jacobson_1989 %>%   clinical_significance(     id = subject,     time = time,     outcome = gds,     pre = "pre",     reliability = 0.80,     m_functional = 30,     sd_functional = 7,     type = "c",     method = "EN"   ) #> Clinical Significance Results (EN) #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Recovered    |  4 |   0.154 #> Improved     | 13 |   0.500 #> Unchanged    |  9 |   0.346 #> Deteriorated |  0 |   0.000 #> Harmed       |  0 |   0.000  jacobson_1989 %>%   clinical_significance(     id = subject,     time = time,     outcome = gds,     pre = "pre",     reliability = 0.80,     m_functional = 30,     sd_functional = 7,     type = "c",     method = "HA"   ) #> Clinical Significance Results (HA Individual Level) #>  #> Category     |  n | Percent #> --------------------------- #> Recovered    |  1 |   0.038 #> Improved     | 16 |   0.615 #> Unchanged    |  9 |   0.346 #> Deteriorated |  0 |   0.000 #> Harmed       |  0 |   0.000 #>  #> Clinical Significance Results (HA Group Level) #>  #> Category   | Percent #> -------------------- #> Changed    |   0.900 #> Functional |   0.163   # And plot your results results <- jacobson_1989 %>%   clinical_significance(     id = subject,     time = time,     outcome = gds,     pre = "pre",     reliability = 0.80,     m_functional = 30,     sd_functional = 7,     type = "c"   )  plot(results)

code: results <- jacobson_1989 %>% clinical_significance(   id = subject,   time = time,   outcome = gds,   pre = "pre",   reliability = 0.80,   m_functional = 30,   sd_functional = 7,   type = "c" )  get_augmented_data(results) #> # A tibble: 26 × 13 #>       id   pre  post change    rci clinical_pre functional_post recovered #>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> <lgl>        <lgl>           <lgl>     #>  1     1  68    62.5   -5.5 -1.43  TRUE         FALSE           FALSE     #>  2     2  74.5  56    -18.5 -4.79  TRUE         FALSE           FALSE     #>  3     3  58.5  58     -0.5 -0.130 TRUE         FALSE           FALSE     #>  4     4  73.5  71     -2.5 -0.648 TRUE         FALSE           FALSE     #>  5     5  78.5  60.5  -18   -4.66  TRUE         FALSE           FALSE     #>  6     6  76    77      1    0.259 TRUE         FALSE           FALSE     #>  7     7  76.5  58.5  -18   -4.66  TRUE         FALSE           FALSE     #>  8     8  63    52    -11   -2.85  TRUE         FALSE           FALSE     #>  9     9  70    65.5   -4.5 -1.17  TRUE         FALSE           FALSE     #> 10    10  75    73     -2   -0.518 TRUE         FALSE           FALSE     #> # … with 16 more rows, and 5 more variables: improved <lgl>, unchanged <lgl>, #> #   deteriorated <lgl>, harmed <lgl>, category <fct>

text: x clinisig object. dataset dataset wish retrieve. Available options "original" (raw original dataset) "wide" (original dataset wide format) "data" (dataset used calculations). default "data"

text: tibble

title: Get Data From A clinisig Object — get_data
code: results <- jacobson_1989 %>%   clinical_significance(     id = subject,     time = time,     outcome = gds,     pre = "pre",     reliability = 0.80,     m_functional = 30,     sd_functional = 10,     type = "c"   )  get_data(results) #> # A tibble: 26 × 4 #>       id   pre  post change #>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1     1  68    62.5   -5.5 #>  2     2  74.5  56    -18.5 #>  3     3  58.5  58     -0.5 #>  4     4  73.5  71     -2.5 #>  5     5  78.5  60.5  -18   #>  6     6  76    77      1   #>  7     7  76.5  58.5  -18   #>  8     8  63    52    -11   #>  9     9  70    65.5   -4.5 #> 10    10  75    73     -2   #> # … with 16 more rows get_data(results, "wide") #> # A tibble: 30 × 3 #>       id   pre  post #>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #>  1     1  68    62.5 #>  2     2  74.5  56   #>  3     3  58.5  58   #>  4     4  73.5  71   #>  5     5  78.5  60.5 #>  6     6  76    77   #>  7     7  76.5  58.5 #>  8     8  63    52   #>  9     9  70    65.5 #> 10    10  75    73   #> # … with 20 more rows get_data(results, "original") #> # A tibble: 60 × 4 #>    subject time    das   gds #>      <dbl> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> #>  1       1 pre    90.5  68   #>  2       1 post   97    62.5 #>  3       2 pre    74    74.5 #>  4       2 post  124    56   #>  5       3 pre    97    58.5 #>  6       3 post   97.5  58   #>  7       4 pre    73.5  73.5 #>  8       4 post   88    71   #>  9       5 pre    61    78.5 #> 10       5 post   96.5  60.5 #> # … with 50 more rows

title: Get Number Of Participants From A clinisig Object — get_n
code: results <- jacobson_1989 %>%   clinical_significance(     id = subject,     time = time,     outcome = gds,     pre = "pre",     reliability = 0.80,     m_functional = 30,     sd_functional = 10,     type = "c"   )  get_n(results) #> # A tibble: 1 × 3 #>   n_original n_used percent_used #>        <int>  <int>        <dbl> #> 1         30     26        0.867 get_n(results, which = "original") #> # A tibble: 1 × 1 #>   n_original #>        <int> #> 1         30 get_n(results, which = "used") #> # A tibble: 1 × 1 #>   n_used #>    <int> #> 1     26

title: Get Reliability Of A clinisig Object — get_reliability
code: results <- jacobson_1989 %>%   clinical_significance(     id = subject,     time = time,     outcome = gds,     pre = "pre",     reliability = 0.80,     m_functional = 30,     sd_functional = 10,     type = "c"   )  results_nk <- jacobson_1989 %>%   clinical_significance(     id = subject,     time = time,     outcome = gds,     pre = "pre",     reliability = 0.80,     reliability_post = 0.85,     m_functional = 30,     sd_functional = 10,     type = "c",     method = "NK"   )  get_reliability(results) #> # A tibble: 1 × 1 #>   reliability #>         <dbl> #> 1         0.8 get_reliability(results_nk) #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   reliability_pre reliability_post #>             <dbl>            <dbl> #> 1             0.8             0.85

title: Get A Summary Table From A clinisig Object — get_summary_table

text: Hageman, W. J., & Arrindell, W. . (1999). Establishing clinically significant change: increment precision distinction individual group level analysis. Behaviour Research Therapy, 37(12), 1169–1193. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0005-7967(99)00032-7

title: Get A Summary Table From A clinisig Object — get_summary_table
code: results <- jacobson_1989 %>%   clinical_significance(     id = subject,     time = time,     outcome = gds,     pre = "pre",     reliability = 0.80,     m_functional = 30,     sd_functional = 10,     type = "c"   )  results_ha <- jacobson_1989 %>%   clinical_significance(     id = subject,     time = time,     outcome = gds,     pre = "pre",     reliability = 0.80,     m_functional = 30,     sd_functional = 10,     type = "c",     method = "HA"   )  get_summary_table(results) #> # A tibble: 5 × 3 #>   category         n percent #>   <chr>        <int>   <dbl> #> 1 Recovered        6   0.231 #> 2 Improved         8   0.308 #> 3 Unchanged       12   0.462 #> 4 Deteriorated     0   0     #> 5 Harmed           0   0     get_summary_table(results_ha) #> # A tibble: 5 × 3 #>   category         n percent #>   <chr>        <int>   <dbl> #> 1 Recovered        2  0.0769 #> 2 Improved        15  0.577  #> 3 Unchanged        9  0.346  #> 4 Deteriorated     0  0      #> 5 Harmed           0  0      get_summary_table(results_ha, which = "group") #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   category   percent #>   <chr>        <dbl> #> 1 Changed      0.900 #> 2 Functional   0.300

title: Plot Clinical Significance Results — plot.clinisig
text: Plot results clinical significance analysis.

title: Plot Clinical Significance Results — plot.clinisig
code: # S3 method for clinisig plot(   x,   lower_limit = 0,   upper_limit = 100,   rci_fill = "grey10",   rci_alpha = 0.1,   diagonal_color = "black",   show = NULL,   which = c("point", "trajectory", "slope"),   include_cutoff = TRUE,   include_cutoff_band = FALSE,   x_lab = NULL,   y_lab = NULL,   color_lab = "Group",   overplotting = 0.02,   ... )

title: Plot Clinical Significance Results — plot.clinisig
text: x clinisig object lower_limit Numeric, lower plotting limit. Defaults 0 upper_limit Numeric, upper plotting limit. Defaults 100 rci_fill String, color (name HEX code) RCI filling rci_alpha Numeric, controls transparency RCI. can value 0 1. diagonal_color String, color (name HEX code) line indicating change. show String. several options color different features. Available "category" (shows categories ) default "recovered" (shows recovered participants) "improved" (shows improved participants) "unchanged" (shows unchanged participants) "deteriorated" (shows deteriorated participants, available) "harmed" (shows harmed participants, available) String. plot type shown? Defaults "point" yields default clinical significance plot. HLM method incorporates multiple measurements per participant, reduction pre post values may remove important information. Therefore, can additionally choose plot either participants trajectory ("trajectory"), participants fitted Empirical Bayes slope ("slope") include_cutoff Logical. clinical cutoff plotted well? Defaults TRUE. include_cutoff_band Logical. method HA, region uncertainty around cutoff can plotted x_lab String, x axis label. Default "Pre" point "Measurement" trajectory slope plot. y_lab String, y axis label. Default "Post" point, "Outcome Score" trajectory, "Fitted Score" slope plot. color_lab String, color guide label. Default "Group". overplotting Numeric, control amount overplotting. Defaults 0.02 (.e., 2% range lower upper limit). ... Additional arguments
